instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in with severe water damage. Cleaned and replaced everything but having difficulty with the backlight fuse. Both pads were beyond bringing back so did scraping in the area to solder replacement fuse and running jumpers on each side of fuse

My problem is with my jumper for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> point pin 1 of the fuse. When I run a jumper to <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> which has <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to the fuse it smokes and the jumper breaks. Have tried several different gage of wire with no luck.

Do I need to run jumper somewhere else with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> or is something else happening here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message:
Ran jumper to <CAPACITOR>C3880</CAPACITOR> just to be sure and same issue occurs. Jumper smokes and melts as soon as power is applied.

Board powers on and works besides no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message: This sounds downright awful especially if the pads for the fuse were blown out. Do you have a short on backlight output? Is PPBUS grounded by chance where the fuse use to sit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message:
If you scratched deep inside the board, possibly got a short with the next copper layer.
Check for short to ground on each pad of F9700.
Same thing check on <DIODE>D9701</DIODE>, w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message:
Have 0hm short on pad 1 of F9700 so yes PPBUS pad is grounded.

<DIODE>D9701</DIODE> not shorted with or without LCD.

What is best thing to do in this situation? Scrap new area for fuse near area possibly and then run jumpers?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message: First, I would say purposefully remove the PPBUS pad where the fuse use to be and see if the short clears. I would consider soldering the fuse directly to pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> and jumping the other pad of the fuse to something like <RESISTOR>R4260</RESISTOR>. That way you completely cut out the cluster fuck of what's left of the fuse pads and run your circuit away from the mess.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
threads.message:
Cut the trace from pad 1/F9700.
The pad 1 can remain grounded, but you must isolate the rest of the trace.
Then solder the fuse as above mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight fuse smoke
